node.title: Threashold for residual
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am working on grain growth model with particles. In my simulations, grain growth stops after certain time and reach a steady state. Although I could see the grain g rowth rate to be reducing with time, They never reach a steady state. instead, dt keeps reducing until the point when the simulation terminates with an error that dt_min is reached. is there a way I can define in my code the minimum threadhold beyond which the residual becomes zero?
Regards,
Ashish

Hello
This is not the normal progression of the simulation. The solver is failing which is why the time step keep getting reduced.
Please see our "troubleshooting failed solves" instructions.
The first step is to identify whether the linear or nonlinear solve is failing
Guillaume

what should be my next step after identifying the fail?
I am certain that non-linear solve is failing.
following is what my executioner block looks like
[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  scheme = bdf2
  solve_type = PJFNK #Preconditioned JFNK (default)
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'hypre    boomeramg'
  steady_state_detection = true
  steady_state_start_time = 0
  steady_state_tolerance = 1e-8
  l_abs_tol = 1.0e-3
  nl_abs_tol = 1.0e-3
  l_tol = 1.0e-3
  l_max_its = 5
  nl_max_its = 5
  nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-3
  start_time = 0.0
  #num_steps = 200
  end_time = 20000000000
  dtmin = 1e-20
  #dt = 1
  line_search = none

  [Adaptivity]
    initial_adaptivity = 0
    refine_fraction = 0.7
    coarsen_fraction = 0.1
    max_h_level = 1
  []
  [TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    cutback_factor = 0.8
    dt = 0.00001
    growth_factor = 1.2
    optimal_iterations = 7
  []
[]

Can you suggest optimum values for these?
Ashish
can you paste the simulation log here?

Here is the output file
0p05.txt

Thé tolerances are super loose
Please tighten the nonlinear convergence criterion. Accepting non converged solutions is not helping the solver finish the transient

l_abs_tol = 1.0e-4
  nl_abs_tol = 1.0e-4
  l_tol = 1.0e-4
  l_max_its = 30
  nl_max_its = 30
  nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-4

will that work. If I go less than this the solve takes really long time. I tried with tight tolerances earlier, but, for every timesteps it was taking such a huge time.

There s no way to know ahead of time if it will be enough.
You can look at improving preconditioning to make the linear solves faster and be able to afford more nonlinear solves.
You should use checkpoitining to make a checkpoint before the problem arises, then tighten the convergence tolerances a few time steps before it occurred

node.title: Periodic function in MOOSE.
node.bodyText:
Good afternoon, I am trying to implement a periodic function in MOOSE.

Currently, I have defined the red points that can be appreciated in the image, and the idea is to repeat the cycle indefinitely.
This is the function defined in just one cycle for the red points in the image.
  [Delta_def]
    type = PiecewiseConstant
    x = '0 20e6 40e6 60e6 80e6 100e6'
    y = '-0.0047629 -0.0074940 -0.0062045 -0.15252 -0.0090877 -0.0048300'
    direction = right
  []

I will be attentive to your comments and thank you so much in advance for your assessment.
Best regards,
Alejandro

Hello
The easiest way to do that will be to use the function you have to define the profile, then use a ParsedFunction with an if condition (or the % operator if it works) to create the periodicity on the initial function
Guillaume

node.title: Convergence Issues with a Second-Order Mixed Partial Derivative in MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
I am currently working on solving an equation with a second-order mixed partial derivative:

The weak form of this equation is as follows:

However, I am encountering convergence issues during computation and can only use JFNK, not PJFNK. I have tried different approaches, including directly computing the residual for the term with the mixed partial derivative using _var.secondSln(), as well as integrating by parts to reduce the mixed partial derivative term to two first-order partial derivative terms.

Despite these attempts, convergence remains unattainable.
In my tests, if I simplify the problem to Mat(x,y)∂F(x,y)/∂y=Q, I can achieve correct convergence by directly computing the residual term for the left-hand side of the equation using _grad_u in the Kernel. However, this approach also has issues since it still requires JFNK instead of PJFNK. When attempting to solve using PJFNK, I receive the following errors:
  Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_PC_FAILED iterations 0
                 PC failed due to FACTOR_NUMERIC_ZEROPIVOT 
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH iterations 0

Does anyone know how to address this issue?

Hello
Are you using automatic differentiation?
Maybe the Jacobian has a large mistake.
There is some advice on convergence issues here:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/application_usage/failed_solves.html
No, I provide the computeQpJacobian() function manually.

then there may be a mistake, or a missing off-diagonal term.
The Jacobian tester or the petsc option to test Jacobians are a good idea to see this
I thought there was no need to use the computeQpOffDiagJacobian() function because there is only one variable, F(x,y).
if there is only one variable and no element-to-neighbor coupling you should be fine
What do you mean by element-to-neighbor? Do you mean partial derivatives?
I mean techniques like mortar coupling or specific treatment at interface kernels

I only used Kernel, BC, and DGKernel, without any complex techniques. This equation, aside from having a mixed partial derivative, doesn't have any other complexities. I'm also not sure if such an equation requires any special stabilization techniques for computation.

I can see DGKernels have off diagonal coupling between the element and the side DoFs.
You should look at example nonAD DG kernels to see how this is handled

node.title: Handling Mixed Second-Order Partial Derivatives in MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hi everyone,
I need to solve an equation that includes a mixed second-order partial derivative with respect to x and y, but I'm unsure how to handle the mixed partial derivative in MOOSE. In 2021, a similar question was asked (##19475), and the recommendation was to use integral transforms for differential reduction. I've tried this method, but MOOSE fails to converge during the computation.
I'm curious if there have been any updates or advancements in how MOOSE handles second-order mixed partial derivatives. I noticed that the code related to the incompressible Navier-Stokes (INS) equations in MOOSE seems to include variables for second-order derivatives (e.g., _second_u_vel(coupledSecond("u"))), although I recall that the INS module does not include mixed second-order partial derivatives.
The specific mixed second-order partial derivative I need to handle is:

Any guidance or insights on how to properly implement this in MOOSE would be greatly appreciated. Thank you!

Hello
I think coupledSecond returns a tensor and you can simply access the off-diagonal component to get the d2f/dxdy
I have never tried but I would expect that to be the solution.
You should make a simple auxkernel with coupledSecond and use it on predefined second order variables, for which you know the correct 2nd order derivatives, to check that it works
Guillaume

I believe you can output the tensor with
std::cout << Moose::stringify(..
If you do _tensor.row(0)(1) you should get the xy mixed derivative
Note that you also need to index by quadrature point with [_qp]
Thank you, it works.

node.title: Moving Shell-Elements to an inactive subdomain (error in MooseVariableBase.C, line 145)
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose-Community,
I have a 3D mesh with some volume-elements in one subdomain and some shell-elements in another subdomain. The moment I try to move the shell-elements into an inactive domain (added by add_subdomain_names), I get the following error:
Assertion `_is_lower_d == _mesh.isLowerD(*it)' failed
A user should not specify a mix of lower-dimensional and higher-dimensional blocks for a variable
at /home/user/projects/moose/framework/src/variables/MooseVariableBase.C, line 145

The inactive domain I tried to move the shell-elements to was previously empty and never used before. I only try to move the shell elements of one subdomain (I do not try to mix element types in one inactive subdomain).
Is it possible to move shell elements to an inactive domain, if the mesh consists also of volume elements?
Thank you for your help.
Jörg

Hello
We'll have to change the code a little bit because we should allow this.
This is more about the elements being 2D in a 3D mesh than being of the "XYZShell" type but I understand what you mean.
Guillaume
let's create an issue

It seems that the error I am experiencing is not primarily related to assigning shell elements to an inactive subdomain. I am therefore closed the issue #28204 as resolved. To #28204 I attached a test model which shows the moving of volume and shell elements with a TimedSubdomainModifier without generating an error.

it should be tied to dimensions of the elements (with dim=2 and dim=3 elements at the same time for a variable being the problem).
If that is the case then this is expected.
I think we could change this if needed

node.title: Cant get MOOSE installed on Lemhi
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
I am currently following these instructions: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/getting_started/installation/inl_hpc_install_moose.html, and I messed something up. I successfully had MOOSE on Sawtooth. Then I tried to add some custom kernels and make the program, but I accidentally did it when I was in Lemhi, and it broke everything.
I then tried to "fix" the install by updating it, but I was not in a login node, so I think that did more damage. I thought the best course of action would then be to just "delete" the files and start over, but that, of course, did not fix anything. What should I do to get MOOSE on either Lemhi, sawtooth or both? I attached an image with the error below.
Thank you for your time, and I apologize for the headache!
Also, I'm just curious why the user needs to have separate instances of moose on Lemhi and Sawtooth. Also, I've seen 2 sawtooth hpcs(1 & 2). Do I need a separate instance of MOOSE on sawtooth 1 and 2 as well?

Hello
Different moose folder for sawtooth and lemhi for sure.
For sawtooth 1 & 2, I think they are the same.
Which modules are you using?
Guillaume
Thanks, good to know! I am just going to be using the phase field module and adding some of my coded kernels.
which HPC modules? the compilers and mpi but the output of module list is what I want to see

The reason for the separation is due to, I suspect, the errors you received after the first "whoops". The two machines are different, with different compiler libraries. When you build on Lemhi (make), and then accidentally continue to develop and build on Sawtooth (additional makes) is when you'll run into compiling issues.
This is why we ask users to create some sort of directory separation (~/projects/sawtooth).
As for starting completely over and still hitting a snag... I think we do have issues with all our moose-dev modules on every cluster at the moment... Can you try to build on bitterroot within a container instead (we don't have instructions for this yet, so I'll walk you through it)?
Gain a shell on Bitterroot:

Then perform the following:
module load use.moose moose-containers moose
moose-shell
You'll be placed into a container with all the fixings. Proceed to build your application as normal (you may need to clean your repo before obtaining a successful build).
NoteThe container will have PETSc, libMesh, and WASP already built! So proceed directly to running make in your application.

TipWe will eventually include these instructions as the only way to develop with MOOSE. That being said, when we do, there will be no need to create directory separations (~/projects/sawtooth; ~/projects/lemhi). Containers are immutable, relocatable objects. They are designed to work everywhere and provide the same experience when doing so.

tagging @loganharbour if he has anything to add

Thank you so much for the help! @GiudGiud Apologies for the misunderstanding. I was using the moose-dev module, and I am planning on using the Paraview one later.

I was able to follow the install procedure and it seems to have installed properly! I was wondering now how you submit batch jobs on bitterroot/inl hpcs. My university uses nano and .pbs scripts. An example file would be awesome! Also considering how low on the totem pole of priority I am, do yall have nay recommendations on how many cores I should use to have a good balance of performance and the jobs not waiting in the queue for days? I also don't really know how to execute a moose code without the use of Conda so some clarification on that would also be great. Thank you so much for your help!
And wow, I did all of this accidentally in a folder called Lemhi. Can I change the name of the folder?

moose-x86_64:cf062e7 [eggejohn@bitterroot1: (master) ~/lemhi/projects/moose/scripts ]

doesnt bitterrout use slurm? I m not sure you can use pbs

cp: cannot create regular file '/opt/libmesh/include/libmesh/inst.898016': Read-only file system

it's trying to install at the wrong location. I dont know why in /opt.
Did you load a module with libmesh?
Let's unload then let's set LIBMESH_DIR to somewhere reasonable.

When you are operating within a container:
NoteThe container will have PETSc, libMesh, and WASP already built! So proceed directly to running make in your application.

So do not try and build PETSc, libMesh or WASP yourself. Containers are immutable. You were attempting to modify things already inside the container and thus: permission denied will show up. There is a way to do this, and if you must, we can walk you through it. But I suspect very few folks need this capability.
As I stated previously, there is still something wrong with every moose-dev module on every one of our cluster machines (Lemhi, Sawtooth, and Bitterroot). And I am not sure we are going to even attempt to fix it! We've been wanting to move away from native builds on our clusters for some time. Moving forwards, its best to stick with using containers on our HPC machines:
module load use.moose moose-containers moose
moose-shell
<do application development>
As for your question about launching jobs via PBS/Slurm, I'm afraid we only have this working for vetted applications at the moment. I am actively looking into a solution for you, and will report back when I have one. This shouldn't be long... I will make this a priority, as I feel this was an oversight on my part telling you "I will never fix the moose-dev module", AND not providing a way for you to run developed applications using a job scheduler!

Thank you for your time and clarification; I am an engineer, not a programmer, so this HPC stuff is very new and confusing to me. Good to know with rebuilding PETSc and the others I would have kept on doing that.
I am comfortable using some bash to run programs/applications though, so how should I proceed if I want to add one kernel to an application and run some tests on any of the HPCS right now? From the answer, it sounds like I have to wait a little bit or use a container which I need some clarification on because I thought this HPC used modules. Thank you again!

Sorry for the delay, I was on vacation last week, allowing myself one hour each day for GitHub discussions/emails... etc.
I think what I need to do is actually fix the current moose-dev modules. I was hoping for a quick solution to using containers for development, but we're just not there yet.
I'll post again when I feel the modules are working.

Sawtooth appears to be fine at the moment. Building everything from PETSc to moose/test. Either another from my team fixed the modules, or our HPC team solved an underlying issue.
Can you perform the following (first, gain entry to Sawtooth):
module purge
module load use.moose moose-dev
Next, we're going to clone MOOSE in a completely new area to eliminate a stale build issue:
mkdir /tmp/my_testing_builds
cd /tmp/my_testing_builds
git clone https://github.com/idaholab/moose
cd moose
git checkout master
Next, lets build the stack:
cd scripts
export METHODS=opt METHOD=opt MOOSE_JOBS=6
./update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh
Stop if PETSc failed. If not, proceed:
./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh
Stop if libMesh failed. If not, proceed:
./udpate_and_rebuild_wasp.sh
Stop if WASP failed. If not, proceed:
cd ../test
make -j 6

node.title: Errors in installing RACCOON
node.bodyText:
Hi all, i followed the steps given on https://hugary1995.github.io/raccoon/getting_started/install.html
But i am getting some errors while executing the 'make' command:
/Users/sunqingpei/projects/raccoon/moose/framework/contrib/hit/src/hit/parse.cc:147:8: error: no member named 'set_type' in 'wasp::HITNodeView'
_hnv.set_type(wasp::BLANK_LINE);
/Users/sunqingpei/projects/raccoon/moose/framework/contrib/hit/src/hit/parse.cc:147:23: error: no member named 'BLANK_LINE' in namespace 'wasp'
_hnv.set_type(wasp::BLANK_LINE);
              ~~~~~~^
/Users/sunqingpei/projects/raccoon/moose/framework/contrib/hit/src/hit/parse.cc:295:28: error: no member named 'BLANK_LINE' in namespace 'wasp'
if (_hnv.type() == wasp::BLANK_LINE)
                   ~~~~~~^
Really appreciate the help!

@Bigdogcat -
This indicates that your of WASP version is out of date with your MOOSE version, and these should be in sync.
That set_type() method and BLANK_LINE enum were added to WASP around 10 months ago on Oct 6, 2023.
I do not see anything on https://hugary1995.github.io/raccoon/getting_started/install.html with updating WASP.
I am not sure if you used those https://hugary1995.github.io/raccoon/getting_started/conda.html Conda steps.
But it appears that the moose-dev Conda package (which is needed for WASP) is not mentioned on that page.
You would need something like https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html for that.
If you are not using that Conda setup, then ./moose/scripts/update_and_rebuild_wasp.sh will need to be ran.
This is in addition to running the update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh and update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh scripts.
It may be best to wait for @hugary1995 to respond with more insight on which of the setups is recommended.
Because the moose-dev=2024.07.19 version at that link above might not be sync with your RACCOON version.
@hugary1995 - Do you have any recommendations about this?
The RACCOON installation guide is outdated. I'm running out of bandwidth for maintaining it, and I am looking for the next maintainer to hand it over. If I don't find one I might have to archive it.
Resolved by referring to #27489 (comment)

It's a little bit embarrassing that I have resolved this tinyhttp error by referring to #27489 (comment). But when I compile, there is still an error
ld: warning: directory not found for option '-L/Users/sunqingpei/miniconda3/envs/moose/lib/gcc/x86_64-apple-darwin13.4.0/9.5.0'
ld: library not found for -lvtkParallelMPI-9.2
clang-16: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
Deleting original response in favor of answering #28224 (reply in thread)

node.title: Using "DiscreteNucleation" to create a nucleus in an existing polycrystal
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE Members,
I am currently working on dynamic recrystallization using MOOSE. Before delving deeper, I tried a simple example involving MOOSE grain growth. In this example, I aimed to initiate two grains, gr0 and gr1, and then create a nucleus with the same grain ID (gr1) after some time steps. I used "DiscreteNucleationForce" as the kernel for this purpose. However, I encountered an issue: after the holding time, the nucleus suddenly disappears (not smoothly), and the other crystal with the same grain ID (gr1) also vanishes.
Can anyone explain why this happens? Is it possible to insert a nucleus with an existing grain ID?
I have attached my ihnput file with is 👍
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

    elem_type = QUAD4 # Type of elements used in the mesh
    uniform_refine = 2 # Initial uniform refinement of the mesh
  
    parallel_type = replicated # Periodic BCs
  []
  [GlobalParams]

    op_num = 2 # Number of grains
    var_name_base = gr # Base name of grains
  []
  [Variables]

    
    [./PolycrystalVariables]
      order = FIRST
      family = LAGRANGE
    [../]
  []

  [Modules]
    [./PhaseField]
      [./GrainGrowth]
        variable_mobility = false
      [../]
    [../]
  []

  [ICs]

    y2 = 1000

    outside = 0
    x2 = 500
    variable = gr0
    x1 = 0
    type = BoundingBoxIC
  [../]
    [./gr1]
      y2 = 1000
      y1 = 0
      inside = 1.0

      variable = gr1
      x1 = 500
      type = BoundingBoxIC
    [../]

      variable = gr1

      type = Reaction
      variable = gr1
    [../]
      [./PolycrystalKernel]
      
      [../]
  []

      type = DiscreteNucleationFromFile
      hold_time = 200
      file = nuclei.csv
  
    [../]
    [./map]

      int_width = 14
      #periodic = gr1

  []

[]

@loganharbour  do you know anything about this?

MSG_NOSIGNAL should come from the <sys/socket.h> system C include. We might have to dig around some to see if it's not supported with an older C library.
From lpeterse/haskell-socket#8 it looks like it might just not be available.
@aclin4 can you try adding #define MSG_NOSIGNAL 0  in the top of that http.C include and see if it compiles?
I can come up with a better solution once I'm online, but this should be a sanity check. We shouldn't be hitting that line of code so even though this is a hacky fix, it should at least get things working for you in the interim.

Hi Logan,
Thanks for getting back on this. Before I was able to try your suggestion, I managed to fix the issue by updating my version of Command Line Tools for Xcode, as it wasn't automatically updated with my MacOS update.
If you want to try and recreate the issue, I think I was getting the error on Command Line Tools for Xcode 11.5 and fixed the issue by updating to version 15.0.
In case anyone runs into a similar issue, try updating Command Line Tools for Xcode via the Apple Developer app store.
Great! Thanks for following up!
I just got the same issue. But updating the command line tool didn't work. Adding "#define MSG_NOSIGNAL 0" worked.
